awd_titl_txt: CRII: CHS: Redesigning Democratized Technology: The Broadening of Citizen Participation in Bottom-Up Technological Innovation
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will contribute actionable insights concerning two key issues about democratizing technology: technological practices remain exclusive in terms of privileged users, and participation in decision-making is unequal. It will do so by exploring two emerging, creativity-centric technology communities as case studies - activist and non-profit oriented independent game developers and creative live audio and video streamers. Its focus on democratizing technology will help computing technologies and technological practices become more inclusive, affordable, accessible, and open to everyday citizens. Its emphasis on mechanisms, strategies, and techniques that broaden the possibility of citizen participation in technological innovation increases the opportunities for and retention of females and underrepresented minorities in science and engineering education. These findings and the developed prototype resulting from this work can be used to inform and address the needs of other computing communities seeking to be more open, accessible, and participative.  This research also promotes public engagement with science and technology on two levels: by generating interest in the science and technology research community to pursue research that supports bottom-up technological innovation, and by directly engaging many of those innovators in this scientific project.
 
The long-term research agenda of this project explores computer-mediated collective innovation practices and is guided by the following research questions: (1) How, if at all, do independent game developers and creative live streamers perceive, understand, and interpret their technological practices as democratized? (2) What mechanisms, strategies, and techniques do they use to support such practices? (3) What requirements and designs for new sociotechnical systems could be identified to better support democratized technological practices for end-user driven technological innovation? This project entails an empirical and conceptual advance in computer-supported cooperative work and human-computer interaction research on bottom-up innovation and participatory culture by using new research contexts and datasets, which have implications beyond the gaming and live streaming communities. It not only discloses how a technological practice can be perceived and interpreted as democratized by everyday citizens, but also elucidates why a community embodies such an interpretation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated two issues concerning democratization of technology (i.e., privileged users and unequal participation in decision-making) by studying two emerging, novel technological communities -- indie game developers and creative live streamers. It also identified requirements and design principles for new sociotechnical systems that could better support democratized technological practices for end-user driven technological innovation and content creation. Indie games are broadly defined as games that are consciously created within alternative production and distribution structures compared to mainstream game companies. The indie game development community as a complex, heterogeneous technology community who pursues alternative ideologies, channels, and infrastructures to innovate game development. Creative live streamers represent a unique community of artists, designers, makers, and technologists to openly share their creative process and practices and directly interact with viewers over live streams, through which learning, collaboration, and mutual help often emerge. Taken together, these two communities' advocacy of values of sharing, open, and innovation, their use of cutting-edge technologies, alternative economic and production model, creative individual activities/expressions/values, collaborative community acts with aspirations of being a counter-culture raise interesting questions about bottom-up innovation, public participation, and the shifting power/labor relations in the modern technology workforce.

This project conducted extensive qualitative, design, and prototype work with both the indie game development community and the live streaming community, including interviews, content analysis of online data, and prototyping a new online platform to better support democratized technological practices for end-user driven technological innovation and content creation. This project has not only disclosed how a technological practice can be perceived and interpreted as democratized by everyday technology users but also elucidated why a community embodies such an interpretation, which adds nuance to the existing literature on democratization of technology. Additionally, this project has identified mechanisms, strategies, and techniques that have been used to support indie game developers' and live streamers' democratized technologies practices. it highlighted (1) four themes that constitute an innovation ecology from the bottom up, including problem solving; collaborative information seeking, sharing, and reproducing; community support; and policy and politics; (2) the importance of small teams, "crafting," and "democracy" in supporting and facilitating middle-tier end-users' engagement with technology; and (3) how U.S. indie game developers' socio-technological practices inject forms of labor, capital, and production into the game development industry by promoting an alternative to business models of game development that depend on free and immaterial labor, building offline networks at different scales to develop collectives that can sustain their production, and emphasizing how distributed collaboration, co-creation, and the use of free tools and middle-ware make game production more widely accessible.

This project also especially focused on the presence and visibility of marginalized technological innovators (e.g., women and LGBTQA+ creative streamers) and how such presence and visibility may affect their social and technological experiences. In doing so, it investigated how, if at all, the design affordances of live streaming platforms per se may affect their presence and visibility. These findings help better understand how new technologies such as live streaming both facilitate marginalized end-users' technological practices (e.g., making them more visible to the public) and pose additional challenges and risks (e.g., more targeted harassment and the mismatch between viewers' expectations and streamers' aspirations) that hinder their technological innovation.

Grounded in these empirical findings, we iterated and elaborated design implications that can better support democratized technological practices for end-user driven technological innovation and content creation. We created and prototyped an online platform as a mobile app called "Indie Toolkit," which can be leveraged to better support democratized technological practices for end-user driven technological innovation and content creation, such as indie game developers. The goal of this toolkit is to (1) help indie game developers to conduct their technological innovation in a more democratized, collaborative, and participatory manner through collaboration, learning and resources, and community features; (2) help them address various challenges in their technological practices by leveraging these features, such as access to information, resources, teamwork, and social support; and (3) provide potential to be easily customized to support other forms of end-user driven creative activities (e.g., DIY making, hacking, crafting, and creative live streaming).

This project has generated 10 publications and received 2 Best Paper Honorable Mention awards at ACM CSCW and iConference. Findings were presented at multiple premier conferences and shared with participants to be disseminated to the broader end-user driven creative community. The project was able to provide research experience and training for 5 graduate students and several undergraduate students. 2 of the 5 graduate students are women and 2 are ethnic minorities. Findings of this project were also incorporated in curriculum development at both graduate and undergraduate levels to help students better understand the profound social, technical, and political implications of emerging computing technologies and discover opportunities for new forms of democratization, creation, and innovation.
